reviewText:
Men of War Assault Squad is the best WW2 real-time tactics game! I've been following this game series ever since the original 'Soldiers Heroes of WW2'. When I tried the demo back then, and realized that you can take the shells out of your broken tank to load a stolen anti-tank gun, and you can scavenge the fallen bodies for weapons and ammunition, and you can take cover behind virtually everything, and you can drive tanks through buldings, I was immediately sold.

This amazing level of detail and authenticity is still present today, and it brings an immense level of control and different tactics that you can use. That comes at the expense of very much micromanagement and almost every key on the keyboard being assigned to some action. That makes it hard for newcomers to pick up, but once you memorized everything, you're going to have a blast.

The multiplayer component is a bit shaky, because it uses an old GameSpy service. That's why I have very high hopes for the upcoming Assault Squad 2, which promises to have full Steam MP integration. The developers have been listening to the community a lot and have published several free updates with lots of new content, so I trust them on this one.

reviewText:
Men of War: Assault Squad is a World War II strategy game developed by Digitalmindsoft and published by 1C Company and was released in February 2011. You, the player, play as different countries from WW2 in historically accurate battles and complete this battles by capturing a set number of strategic points on the battlefield. I will write this review from a single-player perspective by only playing skirmishes, as I did not play this game online or with friends. It will discuss skirmishes, the gameplay within these skirmishes, the graphics and performance, and the overall recommendation.

The main feature of Assault Squad is an underwhelming skirmish mode. A skirmish is a play through recount of a historical battle that is chronological, therefore, there is no proper story campaign. However, there is a recount of the story in the loading screen prior to battle. The skirmishes are split into six categories of America, Germany, Japan, Soviet Union, Britain, and bonus missions, so there is a nice balance of skirmishes. The skirmishes are decent at best, but there is laziness in the mode. The objectives are identical in each mission and country skirmish, which is unfortunate because there is variety in the side missions that add to the skirmish tasks. I did not finish all skirmishes because the lack of variety does not add an incentive for me to complete them, hurting the overall playability of the game. But, I do like the accuracy of the history and the realistic environments within the campaign because the environment adapts as the battle rages on. For instance, if an artillery shell hits the ground it creates a nice and massive hole to showcase the damage. Overall, the skirmishes are a let-down due to the lack of variety.

The gameplay is solid. I commend the developer for making small things count to add to the realistic nature of the game. For instance, a soldier can die in one hit. Furthermore, the gameplay has a very nice strategic concept as a vehicle out powers infantry, though the infantry can flank and destroy the vehicle. The game strikes a good balance between automation and micromanaging, as your soldiers run out of ammo so you have to go to dead bodies and collect ammo, which evenly distributes that ammo among the entire squad. This balance allows the game not to be bogged down by the micromanagement concept, as the battle is real-time and you can easily lose units. Assault Squad has limitations through the type of available units. For instance, each country has unique units, accurate with the historical counterparts, but there is not a wide variety of different units for the player to choose. While this does not overly hurt the game, it could have been expanded upon.

Assault Squad compensates for an underwhelming skirmish mode by having strong graphics and optimised performance. The graphics capture the tone of WW2 through the environment, such as the smoke that arises after a vehicle has been destroyed. Further, the graphics are beautiful when showcasing buildings and the realism of them. Likewise, the performance is great as I run consistently at a 60FPS on ultra-settings.

Men of War: Assault Squad is an overall average game. The skirmish mode is underwhelming mainly due to the lack of variety in objectives. The gameplay is solid in that it is very realistic, which it should be for a WW2 game. The graphics and performances are very good. There were not any notable issues, but the game did not wow me nor did I think the game was good. The lack of incentive to continue playing the game hurt my playability of it. However, there is enough content for others to play this for a long time. I played this game for 15 hours but there is enough content to play through to 30 hours, and with friends at least 60 hours of fun. I played the original Men of War and I liked that, but I felt this was a downgrade. I recommend this game on sale.

Skirmishes: 4/10
Gameplay: 5.5/10
Graphics and performance: 8/10
Replayability: 7/10
Overall: 6/10

Men of War: Assault Squad is a real-time strategy from Digitalmindsoft and published by 1C Company. Men of War: Assault Squad is considered a sequel to the previous game Men of War.

Men of War: Assault Squad retain the same element of gameplay from Men of War, which is micromanagement. But unlike the first Men of War, Men of War: Assault Squad offers a skirmish based mission rather than a story based campaign. This skirmish game is a capture the flag type game which you need to capture all the enemy flag position to win the game. reviewText:
Underatted but incredible.

Picked this game up in the humble-bundle and conviced some friends to do it too... Had massive fun destroying them in 1v1/2v2/3v3/4v4 matches (each one seems like a completely different experience) as well as being destroyed by them and teaming up with them to fight against AI and progress through the map whilst getting rewards along the way.

Looking forward to pick up Men of War: Assault Squad 2 as well as Call to Arms at some point too!

Only downsides are that there is no obvious 'Free for All' type which means you need to have an even number of players for it to be a fair game (each player gets 100CP to spend on units, meaning the larger team always has an extra 100 to spend) as well as the fact that the system that was used for multiplayer having been shut down (the only ways to play multiplayer are throuh programs such as Hamachi, Gameranger, Tunngle or by just using LAN if you're on the same network).

I would reccomend getting this game definitely, but if you have the money to spare then Men of War: Assault Squad 2 or even Call to Arms (although it's early access) may be a better option due to more features as well as a more expansive multiplayer system which will also allow you to fight with/against random players and not just your friends or people you know.

Performance is a little iffy in terms of seemingly having fps that is dependant on how many units are on the field no matter what your PC's specs are (many units = lag, especially tanks or other vehicles)

If I had to rate it out of 10 I would give it an 8/10, it's a great game but has a few flaws which are seemingly solved in the sequel.

There are few games that I've had as much fun playing with friends than this.

If you have a tank in battle for a prolonged ammount of time you may find your self out of HE, AP, or the covited APCR(I will expand on ammo types and options in the next section). Machine guns can run black, and so can snipers. Every one is prone to running completely black on ammo. The cool thing is you can always scavange, many times in my American play I found myself picking up and MP40 when I felt like it may be more effective for the close range fighting that was happening. All weapons and all ammo drops when units die, and can be picked up, unless the unit is blown up. The game also allows you to buy a supply truck completely loaded with 1000s of rounds of ammo.

Also each unit has many options as to weapons they can use, unlike CoH, you can actually have unit switch to a side arm, or switch to grenade, you have so much more control of each man on the field. Where this become most evident it with the armor, This game has some of the best tank physics I have ever seen, when you shoot something with an AP round, you can actually see the hole if it punctures, as well as it hits every on in its path just like a real AP round. It does not just blow up the tank, it blows a hole through it. That is if you actually get a clean hit with a big enough cannon. This is the best part of this game, tank on tank battles. I had a single Stuart take on anything the Jap army could send, That same tank was completly worthless against the germans. Super realistic and fun, and allows for complete control.
My last point and best part about this game, is the direct control. If you just hit E on any unit it gives you complete control. You aim the weapon, fire it, and move with the WASD. Where as normally in an RTS you just right click to attack, in this you can move and attack, with the most possible control, especially with tanks. Moving into postion with a sherman and hitting a Panzer IV point blank with a 76mm APCR Is one of the coolest things you can do.

From a game play standpoint, I got the whole thing on sale, with all the DLC. Which comes with 5 mission for each of the Russian, German, American, Japanese, and Common Wealth factions. Play slow and enjoying it took me 8 hours to beat the USA campagn. So a lot of paytime there. TONS of units!!

Great fun, Cheap game, do it!

Ever wanted to fight a war, more so a World War that too in real time,than this is your game.It is an absolute mammoth of a game.Men of war assault squad is not for the faint of heart, so weak of heart read it  at your own risk.


Men of war assault squad is a game well crafted ,to suit the need of any five years old ,who ever wanted to or did or does play with toy soldiers.The game has more than one campaigns and you can play in the skirmish mode as any of the allied nations,the common wealth even Germany.You start off each game with a basic squad and as you progress through, you have to capture enemy flag points to gain more troops or bonuses.There is smooth progression through levels as you capture each check point.At first generally light vehicles are allowed,at the next point you get your hands on heavier automobile troops.Than gradually bombers and even ship bombardments.


One thing that is going to attract any tactician is the fact that as you play as various factions you have to face different terrain types like tundra,farms,cities,towns,desert, and in each you have to adapt to a different form of war fare.In some snipers may rule the roost, in others heavy tanks and infantry.Likewise you have at your disposal every ww2 unit type, that was ever used in this war in the game.There are realistic commands you can give to your units like suppress fire,fire machine gun,heal a unit,or drive a car.Which adds an aura of realism.



As you play through various factions, you are deigned to face various battlefields which they faced in the war.There are typically nine flagpoints to capture, to win a level or a battlefield and each checkpoint is vital for even leaving one out can force you not to win the battle and proceed to the next level.The game is atmospheric for as you play you face different types of conditions in which to not just keep fighting but to survive with the forces at your disposal.There are many pros to this brilliant game

reviewText:
Coming from someone who was a big fan of Relic COH and Warhammer series, this is definitely way better.

Pro:

Amazing detail and realism. All ballistics are modelled physically. There is no life bar on tanks instead it depends of physics and penetration, any parts that are damaged will result different effect.

A lot of different tactics to try out.

Environments are very detailed and battlefield changes dynamically, building can be destoryed, wreckage block tank's path and create new cover etc. No two game played out the same way.

For me it's a pro, there's a lot of micro management down to the manually manage ammunition of each individual soldier and gas up vehicles manually. Some player might not like this though.
---
Con:

Graphics are functional, but nothing to write home about. Audio gets repetitive after a while, all units repeat the same lines to acknownlege your commands.

The game is very unforgiving, be prepared to save an reload a lot. Even the best tank can be one-shot killed if you are not careful. Sometime feels like a puzzle game where you are carefully removing enemies' defence one piece at a time. At the writing of this review only 8.4% of players completed the first mission on normal difficulty, so don't be shy to start out in easy difficulty.

No stories to speak of, just go from south part of the map to the north that's about it. If you want story you should try other MOW titles.

The game model the ballistic of every bullets, so you need a good CPU, instead of GPUs like other games. Even on my i7 3770 the game can slow down in very large battles. Not game breaking but you should be aware of this if you have older machines.

---
Conclusion, Hardest RTS I've ever played, period. It is so cruel... Anyone up to a real stiff challenge should try this. I'd give it 8/10.

reviewText: This is a different kind of strategy game. There's no silly basebuilding, resource gathering, or other superflous stuff. Its multiplayer is a very refined, distilled version of MoW's great multiplayer, and is very well balanced overall. If you don't mind the realism or intense micro, this is a game worth checking out, at least.

reviewText:
While it's an interesting game, there is a very steep learning curve. For someone who loves RTS games but sucks at PVP, this was a sorry disappointment when I learned I could not play cooperatively with a friend.

The interface is wonky. It's difficult to select squads of troops and common controls like shift-click to select and deselect individual units do not function. The campaigns are incredibly frustrating even on easy due to very narrow maps an inability to flank your opponent. Furthermore the campaign is scripted and tedious even when you beat your opponent. It's a relentless process of bulking up your forces and smashing the enemy's defenses head on (because you can't flank) and then waiting two or three hours with no fast-forward while scripted enemy attacks send predictable waves of troops and tanks at you. That isn't strategy. That's turtle tactics followed by spam.

Multiplayer options are harshly limited. There's no CPU players. Manpower points (currency to buy units) are extremely unclear. I don't know how to view how many you have or at what rate you gain more. Command points (value of units you are allowed to command) default to 80 which is barely enough for a couple of tanks, much less troops to support them. The max, which I think is 160 or 180 or something, still limits the size of your army more than I like. There's only one game mode and it's capture the points. What happened to bases? I'd like an enemy base to go destroy and experience a real feeling of victory. Not sit on a flag until the timer runs out in a glorified King of the Hill RTS.

Men of War 2 is allegedly going to have cooperative gameplay. I look forward to this. Don't get me wrong--the concept of the game is a good one. But, don't spend your money on this unless there's a good sale going on. Otherwise maybe the sequel will be better. This one is interesting enough for me to be interested in the sequel.

reviewText:
Clunky, budgeted, and sometimes brutally unfair thanks to luck alone, Men of War: Assault Squad is still a rock-solid title with its own unique attributes that set it apart from Company of Heroes and other WW2 RTS titles.

What Men of War does best is its keen focus on mimicking the reality of war. There is no such thing as a bottomless magazine, an unlimited fuel tank, or a tank with more rounds than potential targets. There is no be-all, end-all weapon to any situation and every engagement demands its own proportionate response. Wasting troops, ammunition, or even just the fuel in a vehicle can cripple that unit in engagements to come or complicate matters beyond reason.

Did you use up all the high-explosive shells in a tank and now have to face off against dug-in infantry? Good luck trying to snipe them with armor-piercing rounds. Did you fire off all your mortars in a team and now have to destroy an anti-tank gun or lose one of your expensive armored vehicles? Have fun waiting for a new mortar team or supply truck while your tank takes fire it can't respond to.

Range, lethality, and mobility all play crucial roles; tanks can fire far and wide across the map and receive attacks from field guns at even further distances. Vehicles can and will be destroyed in a single shot from a position far across the map or left crippled and useless by a strike to their treads, turret, or main gun. Critical anti-tank infantry or machine gunners can be shot out from under you by snipers, artillery, or even just an unlucky ricochet off of a tank's armor, all happening in the blink of an eye.

Even as brutal as Men of War can be, there are often moments of forgiveness to take advantage of. Vehicles left unuseable are usually left abandoned in a state that can be salvaged. Though time-expensive, all infantry can repair a badly crippled, seemingly useless heavy tank back into fighting condition and crew it. A single rifleman with luck and determination can be used to repair and steal a damaged enemy tank right out from under their noses and bring it back to base to be fully crewed and put back to work. Most infantry fall injured rather than killed outright and swift management of a combat medic can bring decimated squads back into the fight with minimal losses. Valuable weapons can be scavenged, stolen, and re-supplied in the heat of battle by any unit, allowing a dismounted tank crew to become a formidable close quarters assault team when the right tools are left to take.

A solid foundation of realism and hard-hitting micromanagement make Men of War a game worth playing, but it can often be questionable in its aesthetics department. Sometimes bizarre, universally short unit responses, average or above-average quality music with little dynamic manipulation, and a sound system that leaves much to be desired, even as much as the sounds themselves are of good quality, all contribute to an uneven audio experience. Animations that can range from goofy to floaty to eye-catchingly strange hold down its otherwise surprisingly good model quality.

Overall, from my short experience in the game, Men of War is a series I wish I had gotten into sooner. Its short list of failings hardly dent what is, in the end, a game well worth its price tag. As a warning to all who consider purchasing it, I would like to note that, with GameSpy down, multiplayer may be difficult to get into or even impossible for those with problematic connections; services like GameRanger are required to do more than singleplayer, as my own experience tells me.

If a tank is damaged, it can be abandoned, or the crew can leave the tank to repair it and get back in.

Aside from Tank on Tank combat, Infantry combat also feels very fleshed out. Units can and will be suppresed (however, there will be no alert, they will all simply just fall to the ground and crawl to the nearest waypoint you set for them), as well as realistic logistics. Super in-depth, super detailed, super good. Not only can you steal enemy vehicles and guns, you can steal those vehicles' supplies and use them yourself, and then ASSUME DIRECT CONTROL with E and turn the game into a third-person shooter. You can control the inventory of individual infantry down to their damn hats and the bullets in their gun. The environments are almost entirely destructable to a striking degree of detail, which leads to awesome moments like when the bomber you call in for an airstrike is shot down by enemy forces (Yes, you can do that too) and it crashes into a house and knocks it to pieces.
The only two complaints I have about this game are that you can't commandeer everything on the field (Battleships, a German artillery piece in one or two missions, some boats, etc), and that there are too few singleplayer missions: only three per faction, plus the American tutorial mission. I suppose this could stem from the fact that they're all taken from real battles that faction actually won, but I think the base game could stand to have a little more replay value. Still, though, given how much fun it is to play the missions that are there, it doesn't hurt the game much.

5/4/2015: I'm forced to edit my review based on my having played the sequel to this game, Assault Squad 2. It's still an excellent game, but 2 actually has everything this game has, and more - more missions, working online multiplayer, and engine improvements. This is still an excellent game, but pick up the sequel instead.

reviewText:
MoW: AS is a very tough RTS. You have the ability to control anything from a single soldier to an entire platoon. Combat is intensely realistic as a platoon of infantry in the open can be cut down in seconds. Tank on Tank combat is excessively realistic to the point where most players learn why many strategists would only use tanks with infantry escort. Tracks can get blown off, guns can get destroyed, crew can get sniped from inside of the tank, and ammo racks can detonate, all depending on where a shot is placed. If a tank is damaged, it can be abandoned, or the crew can leave the tank to repair it and get back in.

Aside from Tank on Tank combat, Infantry combat also feels very fleshed out. Units can and will be suppresed (however, there will be no alert, they will all simply just fall to the ground and crawl to the nearest waypoint you set for them), as well as realistic logistics. No unit has infinite ammunition supplies, and if you're running low, your best option is to loot an enemy's corpse for extra ammunition, as ammunition types are universal amongst weapons with examples such as: Rifle Ammo, Pistol Ammo,  Shotshells, Machine gun belts, ect. This may not be completely realistic, but it's enough to keep the game steamlined just enough to keep gameplay fun, but not mindless.

reviewText:
Spent 2 hours collecting chickens, Beef, and Crates of Beer, while fighting Rebels.
Best 2 hours spent in several years.

Serious Review:

Pros:
-Old-School inventory management, which is very refined and is rarely bothersome
-Realistic Ballistics in combat, be it Vehicular or Infantry
-Takes some common sense to play
-Hilariously out of place Bonus Missions
-Endless Strategy available
-Sturmtiger. 'nuf said
-Better AI than most modern AAA titles
-Very well balanced
-Long campaign, due to some battles taking a few hours to do, as the AI, though not UBERHAXRNOVA, WILL punish you for leaving a gap in defences, and will counter your units very nicely.
-Good learning curve
-Outstanding graphics for a game of it's time, much better than other RTS titles released later
-Very good economy system
-Rarely overwhelming, the Minimap helps alot too, as it let's you plan ahead in the battle, and stay up-to-date on enemy Movements
-Destructible cover, buildings, etc...
-Murphy's Laws occur on anything and everything mechanical. Seriously.
-Vehicles can be repaired after taking damage, but don't expect to have a quick repair, at least not after any kind of serious damage.
-Vehicles can run out of fuel, adding a huge tactical element (Dang it Germany, Y U NO USE JAPANESE CARS!? )
-Well populated map with lots of nooks and crannies to explore and setup mortars and other Defences
-Awesomely huge fighting when it turns into an infantry-based battle, with ALOT going on.
-Real sense of accomplishment when you complete a long, intense, battle against all odds
-Runs on Windows 8/8.1 without any issues
-Great ingame music
-Very well optimized, even for lower-end, aging machines

Cons:
-A battle on harder difficulties can last 4-5 hours towards the end of the game, so this can go either way
-Can get campy-ish towards the end of a mission, due to the AT guns and the trenches,etc..

reviewText: Assault Squad is pure, gritty, and often unpredictable, battlefield strategy. Tank combat is seriously satisfying and the ability to directly control any unit opens up a degree of precision not possible in other titles. reviewText:
MoW: AS is a very tough RTS. You have the ability to control anything from a single soldier to an entire platoon. Combat is intensely realistic as a platoon of infantry in the open can be cut down in seconds. Tank on Tank combat is excessively realistic to the point where most players learn why many strategists would only use tanks with infantry escort. Tracks can get blown off, guns can get destroyed, crew can get sniped from inside of the tank, and ammo racks can detonate, all depending on where a shot is placed. If a tank is damaged, it can be abandoned, or the crew can leave the tank to repair it and get back in.

Aside from Tank on Tank combat, Infantry combat also feels very fleshed out. Units can and will be suppresed (however, there will be no alert, they will all simply just fall to the ground and crawl to the nearest waypoint you set for them), as well as realistic logistics. No unit has infinite ammunition supplies, and if you're running low, your best option is to loot an enemy's corpse for extra ammunition, as ammunition types are universal amongst weapons with examples such as: Rifle Ammo, Pistol Ammo,  Shotshells, Machine gun belts, ect. This may not be completely realistic, but it's enough to keep the game steamlined just enough to keep gameplay fun, but not mindless.
